For me, still my preferred single player game all these years later, it's N++. It has over 4000 levels, is challenging as all fuck if you're into 100% completion (even if you aren't it's still challenging as fuck), only requires three buttons, and it's easy enough to listen to music or a podcast or something while you play it without being drawn out of the game.
The only downside you might find is that there isn't any story to it at all, but the challenge makes up for that. Graphics are basic as the come if you're a grafixfag. There's no cheap deaths in it though which is a big one for me. If you die then you know it was your fuck up and your fuck up only that caused it. It's cheap as heck for what you get too.
There is no downside to it unless you're a pleb because it's a certified pleb filter.

posts.sub: Images of Tohru and Kurumi Being Friends for a Maid Sticker
posts.com:
Good Afternoon /wsr/!

I am working on a project called Kurumi MaidCard. I named it after the vampire maid from touhou because she is nice and she helped me with math a lot of times.

A MaidCard will be an image that on top has an anime maid and the title of the data on the card and whatever other additional info the maker wants. Beneath that, probably a solid black line and then a Maid Space containing the data (source code for a Computer Program).

People will be able to load the Maid Card in Kurumi MaidCard to see the text.

This format will allow any image sharing platform to double as a code sharing platform.

The upper part with the maid image is called a Maid Sticker. It will be ignored by the machine and is instead there to make it easy for a human to tell the cards apart. This idea is inspired by the stickers they used to put on Super Nintendo games.

Attached is a Tohru. I will put Kurumi in a subsequent post. I want an image of them being friends with a pretty font that says "Kurumi MaidCard".

You don't have to use these images of the characters. They are provided just so you know who to look for.

Thank you /wsr/ for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295333
>How do I embed files into bmp like this?
- create image with dead space at the bottom, like a big long gradient fill or something
- save as a 24-bit BMP
- bust out your calculator, subtract the length of your archive from the length of your BMP
- dd if=archive of=bmp conv=notrunc seek=<number you calculated>
- convert to PNG in imagemagick

>why this works?
- zips will look for their directory at the end of the file, not the start
- 4chan strips non-image data, but the zip is not non-image data, it is image data
- 4chan strips executables and archives, but because the archive is compressed by PNG's image compression it doesn't look like an archive

Sordid and disreputable.

Examples as applied to the 3 named series:
Watari-kun - starts with MC being hounded by a selfish and aggressive girl, who wants to non-sexually pair with him because he was the only stability in her personal life. MC instead asks out another girl who is known to be the paragon of virtue; this is immediately revealed to be false, as she is secretly sexually aggressive due to having low self-esteem.

Gleipnir - starts with female blackmailing the MC into doing her bidding. Devolves into a soft love triangle when it's revealed that she is hunting her sister, who is the previous girlfriend of MC.

Suzuka - two hard-working athletes attempt a relationship, despite being a terrible fit for each other. MC is extremely low IQ and terrible at communication. Female slowly revealed to have a significantly bad personality and impossibly high standards. Disreputable actions, poor judgement, and push them into a long-term relationship that has severe negative externalities (and 1 very positive externality) on their friends, family, and related social institutions.

posts.sub: Animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a city
posts.com:
I need help finding an animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a big city. I can give you all the details I can remember.

Plot: A little boy and his sister somehow get lost in a big, trashy city. At some point in the movie, the little boy loses his sister in a huge group of people during what looks like rush hour. The sister is swept away in a big, dramatic scene as they both frantically try to find each other.

The people clear and the boy realizes that his sister is nowhere to be scene. The boy then goes on a journey through the city to find his sister and meets a bunch of weird throwaway characters along the way. I remember one of the characters being a rude hotdog vendor smoking a comically large cigar and ashing in the hotdog water.

Eventually, the kid meets a man in a subway station at night. The boy was startled by how gruff and intimidating the man looked, but was calmed when the man turned away from him and laid down in a pile of newspapers. I remember a sappy, sad orchestral song began to play as the kid realized that the man was homeless.

The two of them talked, had a heart-to-heart, yadda yadda yadda, then the kid revealed that he lost his sister in the city and had been looking for her all day. The homeless man then decides to join the boy on his journey to find his sister.

The two leave the subway and a montage of them meeting more strange, rude and "wacky" characters plays. The montage ends with two of them ending up at the entrance of a dark, "spooky" alleyway. The boy is too scared to go inside the alley, but the homeless man tells the boy something like he's been in lots of alleys like this one, so he's got nothing to worry about.

The two of them walk into the alley. The kid looks really nervous as he hesitantly walks behind the homeless man. A scuttling sound echoing through the alley and makes the kid turn around. When he looks back, the homeless man in gone.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A voice says something like "up here, child" and the kid looks up to see a giant spider wearing a black suit, a top hat, and what I remember as four monocles on half of his eyes. The spider asks why the kid is scared, then the kid answers that he lost his friend in the alley.

The spider slowly crawls down from the alley wall and says something like "if he was a friend, why would he leave you hear all alone?" I should also note that the spider had a posh English accent and a deep voice.

The spider starts to sing in a kind of slow, opera-esque voice. These are the lyrics I remember, but not sure how accurate they are after so many years.

"Don't you want a friend? A special kind of friend? I will be there 'till the end. I'm just that kind of friend. I may look a bit scary, perhaps a tad too hairy, but a gentleman's cane I carry. But I understand why you're wary."

The giant spider then weaves a piano from his webs and starts playing an upbeat, jazzy sounding song about how he can be the boy's new friend and how lots of people in the city wouldn't make good friends for the boy.

The musical number was full of visual gags, the one I remember the most was the spider playing the drums, the piano and a saxophone or trumpet all at once. The song starts to pick up in speed, the kid is playfully picked up by the spider and set on his back, and they both start dancing.

The song gets faster and I think the lyrics get more revealing about the spider's intentions, then the spider crawls up the alley wall with the kid still on his back. The music crescendos on a shot of the kid's shocked face and then cuts to a shot of the homeless man stuck in a giant web with webbing covering his mouth.

That's right about the time my little brother would start whining about how the movie was scaring him and that he wanted to turn it off. We had a VCR in the living room, so if you watched something, the whole family did, and I only got to watch maybe 30 minutes of it twice.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295251

My little brother and I would get into fights because I wanted to watch the rest of the movie but he couldn't make it passed the end of the spider's song. I remember the lyrics to the opening of the song to this fucking day because I used to try to scare my brother by singing the lyrics to him whenever our parents weren't around.

We only had the film for a little bit before we had to return it to the library (not sure if many other libraries have DVDs or VHS tapes, but ours back in Sault Ste Marie, Michigan in 2003 did). Once again, I don't remember the name of the movie or when it was made, but the animation style looked like it could've been a late 80's or early 90's movie.

I know it's been a long-ass post, but I really want to find this movie again so I can finish it with my little brother after all these fucking years. If any of you remember this movie, please fucking tell me what it is. Been looking everywhere by searching "spider wearing suit movie," "kids get lost in city movie," and shit like "giant spider musical movie."

Help would be greatly appreciated.

What genres of entertainment do you usually enjoy? Do you have any favorite movies or TV shows? Video games? Books? >>1295158
Download them via torrents and watch them with a media player. I'd recommend either MPC-HC or MPV, but both have their own learning curves, and while I wouldn't describe either as being difficult to learn how to use, if you want something that will work out of the box and play anything I'd recommend VLC in the short term.

Most anime is distributed as either MP4 or MKV file types. MKVs are the standard for most people, as they're better for handling multiple different subtitles and audio streams. However they don't play well with browsers or many media devices, hence the need for a dedicated media player. If you watch on a game console or smart TV, MP4 files are the way to go. You'll be more limited in options, but do what you gotta do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295266
>I was thinking about building a super cheap PC with used parts that will cost me $100 or less
Keep shopping, you can do way better than a barebones Ivy Bridge motherboard.

You should be probably accept that at your budget you're not going to get a 1l computer with decent performance, so revise your expectations accordingly.

If you don't need it to be 1l, there's plenty normal-sized computers where you can get a Haswell or newer, plus it actually comes with RAM, storage and a processor, for under $100. Look on Gumtree and stuff.

If you're determined it must be 1l, and you're already looking at $60 for just a motherboard, give a serious thought to Atom. You can get a used N6005 full system for $150-200, or a brand-new one for $250-300, and it will be both smaller and faster. The CPU is technically slower, but its onboard graphics are a decade more modern, and it has more RAM and PCIe bandwidth, so the overall experience will be miles better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295266
>So is there better chip for this thing
Not really, you're constrained by TDP. Lenovo's processor offerings imply a TDP budget of 35W, and even the 3770T goes over that.

Despite the i5 branding, the 3470T is actually an i3: it has hyperthreaded dual-cores, not quad cores like an i5 is supposed to have. Lowest TDP real i5 is 3570T, but it's 45W. I don't think you can exceed 35W, you'd need a new power supply and probably better cooling, and you might well be running the CPU VRMs beyond their design.

Prosecutors don't like the idea that you know about jury nullification, but it's just a fancy name for the logical consequence of the jury's verdict being de-jure correct. posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.com:
Situation

I have 2 servers
1 VPS and 1 Bare metal both have 1 public IPv4
Bare metal is running Proxmox with several NAT'd VM
I want to route all VM traffic through the VPS (preferably with portforwarding) with WireGuard

Running WireGuard on the Baremetal host works and I can connect through the VPS to e.g a HTTP server

What do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295183
So you have a working Wireguard connection between the VPS and bare metal machine?
Then all you have to do now is to set up routing on the bare metal server to route all virtnet traffic through the VPN interface, and then tell the VPS to forward packets from VPN (MASQUERADE in iptables). This will allow VMs to access the internet through the VPS.
To make the VMs publicly available through the VPS, you need to configure DNAT on the VPS to forward certain ports to the bare metal server, and then on the bare metal server another DNAT Which forwards each of those ports to their respective VM IPs.

Quite a bit of fiddling but certainly doable.

posts.com:

I want to switch to Linux but i have never used it and have limited information about it.
What distros would you recommend to somebody who is coming from only ever using windows?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1295300
Kubuntu 22.04 (Ubuntu + KDE Desktop Environment), pic related. Very easy, a lot of available software, taskbar looks like Windows.

Fedora Workstation 37 (Stock GNOME). Rock solid and very good looking, but has limited customization and the GNOME desktop is way too different to what you're used to.

Xubuntu 22.04 (Ubuntu + XFCE Desktop Environment). Very light desktop, works on very old computers, barely any changes over the years, if you like stability.

You can try all these three without deleting your existing operating system, using Live USB. Another recommendation is to try using Linux available software on Windows first to see if they're capable of doing what you need with your computer before jumping to Linux. Finally, don't expect Linux to be Windows, you will have to learn a lot of new things.

>Intel kept the same overall design for years.
That's just not true: 8700K, the sequel to 7700K, has 6 cores instead of 4, 9700K has 8 cores, and 9900K has 8+HT. 1151v2 was a major performance improvement, as even though the cores remained much the same, 1151v2 improved the power delivery that was holding them back. 1200 continued the trend with 10900K (10+HT).

Yes, 11700K and 11900K may as well have been reprises of 9900K, and are regarded by some as a step backwards, but 9900K is a huge step forward from 7700K, it's literally twice the processor.

I am trying to port some NesC code from an interface that has a register implementation, to one which doesn't.

Old interface:
async command error_t reg_read(uint16_t slave_addr, uint8_t reg, uint8_t *val);
New interface:
async command error_t read(i2c_flags_t flags, uint16_t addr, uint8_t length, uint8_t* data);

What I don't particularly understand is, where does the 'register' argument go in the new one? How do I tell my slave device that I want to read at this register?

For example, the function:

bool _interrupt_polarity() {
uint8_t int_pol;
call I2CReg.reg_read(41, 0x30, &int_pol);
int_pol = (int_pol >> 4) & 0x1;
return int_pol ? 0 : 1;
}
makes perfect sense to me using the old one - the device is on address 41, and I want to read the value of the register at 0x30. How should I express this using the second interface?

https://github.com/tinyos/tinyos-main/blob/master/tos/interfaces/I2CReg.nc
https://github.com/tinyos/tinyos-main/blob/master/tos/interfaces/I2CPacket.nc
